body:
@raphaccf, thanks for reporting.
It sounds like this might be an issue specific to the AutoARIMA interface, will investigate.
Perchance, have you observed this in other estimators?

Hypothesis of what's going on: `update_params=True` works as intended, but `update_params=False` fails to skip the test points passed to the `update` call.
Thanks for your response. Actually, I also tested with auto.ets, and I identified  the same behavior.

Hm, yes, I'm able to reproduce this on my local system (3.8, win, main).
Any comments that help tracking down the issue are appreciated.

My first suspicion was that the model's `cutoff` is not updated correctly, hence the `fh` will be relative to the wrong `cutoff`, from `fit` rather than `update`. But that's not true, the `cutoff` seems to be updated correctly (by the base class).
So it does not seem to be a framework issue.

Hence, I now suspect that there is some systematic issue in how the `fh` is passed to the models, in the concrete classes.
If correct, the wrapped models should be asked to forecast at [number of time points seen in update] plus [relative fh], but probably they are just asked to forecast at [relative fh], since the implementer did not anticipate a situation in which the time point last seen is *not* the same as the time point last fitted.

@raphaccf, I'll look into this, since it seems like an important use case.

If you have time, would you be able to help with a list of the estimators where you think this is a problem?
You can loop over all forecasters by using `registry.all_estimators(estimator_types="forecaster")`.
I'll check AutoARIMA and AutoETS first.

Just for information, if anyone else is looking at this:
the bug is a discrepancy between conceptual scientific behaviour and actual behaviour.
Running `update(update_params=False)` over 6 time periods and then asking for a forecast 1 period ahead (with the model fitted before the update) should in generael not be identical with a forecast for the 1st period of the updated time period, from the data previously seen.
Another question is how, if at all, one would test this. The forecaster is interface compliant, it just doesn't output what one would expect of the specified behaviour if an ARIMA model were used.

>If correct, the wrapped models should be asked to forecast at [number of time points seen in update] plus [relative fh], but probably they are just asked to forecast at [relative fh], since the implementer did not anticipate a situation in which the time point last seen is not the same as the time point last fitted.

Yes, I think that's exactly what is happening. `pmdarima` assumes an internal cutoff which is always the last data point seen. The internals are using the `sktime` forecaster's cutoff (which has been updated) instead of the `pmdarima` cutoff, which leads to this behaviour in the one case where a discrepancy can arise (the `update(update_params=False)` case).

@raphaccf, I've looked into this now. It seems there are two things happening:

* cutoff handling in `sktime`'s interface to `pmdarima` - due to that, the `pmdarima` is asked to predict with a cutoff, as if `update(update_params=False)` never happened. This can be changed.
* `pmdarima`, and `statsmodels` on which it is based, does not seem to be able to make forecasts with fixed model parameters on data different from which it was fitted on. I may just be missing how to call it, but neither `pmdarima` nor `statsmodels` `fit` and `predict` seem to offer this functionality.

If the second is correct, the best we could do at `sktime` is to return the forecasts that the model would have produced for the same time stamps *before* `update` was called.

May be worth asking a question on `statsmodels` or `pmdarima`, and if the lack of this feature is confirmed, then raising an issue?
Franz, thank you so much for all the energy you put into this investigation. I understand the aspects you mentioned, and I will follow your suggestion and ask them. Thanks again.

well, there is still an `sktime` aspect to this, namely, intended behaviour on `update_params=False` - it's not *just* a `statsmodels` issue (see above, "two things happening"). I'll put the `sktime` specific one on the todo list, hence I'm reopening the issue. 

Depending on the answer in `statsmodels`, there may also be actions arising (a bugfix, or a "suggested enhancement")
@raphaccf, can you kindly link your issue on `statsmodels` or `pmdarima` here?
Sorry Franz, I'm new to github discusssions, but you mean: open my issues respectavily int statsmodels and pmdarima github's Issues, than get a link from it and post it here?
